column4: So anyone know what the Ubuntu equivalent to Device Manager is?
not that I know of personally, there's various tools, depends on what you want to achieve
Trying to scan my Bluetooth dongle. No Ubuntu native drivers for the pup, so I've gotta find out its model or serial considering it's unmarked and I swear to all it was repackaged.
there's a CLI tool called lsusb
open up terminal and type that command in
open up terminal and type in "lsusb" (without quotes)
probably the other 3 are just USB headers (i.e. there's soldering point for it but no actual hardware bits are soldered onto it and made visible outside the machine
there's lots of other potential variables but that's not ubuntu related
doesn't really help, what you actually need is the pci:id or in this case the usb:id, which is in the form of XXXX:XXXX
no, probably not a good idea, just pastebin (not paste) your lsusb output
have you pastebinned your lsusb output?
it allows simpler pasting, without using hand to paste any outputs
into a website called pastebin.. like pastebin.com
well whichever, but for convenience sake use that

so that I can see what you're seeing and maybe able to assist you further without you venturing back to windows or pasting more than 3 lines into this channel and getting silenced by the bots for flooding
1131:1004 <--- that is the most important valuable piece of info you'll need fyi

remember that same line you pasted to me something about integrated corp? and I said that piece of info is useless, what I need is the pci:id or in this case the usb:id of the device, which is on the same line as that thing you pasted
with that bit of info you can paste that directly into google query and see the support info/status on the device, etc
either way is up to you, if you want to learn, probably a good idea is to start filtering out yourself :) good practise
